The Act may be cited as the "Violence Against Children Act of 2003". Congress finds that children under 18 account for 12% of crime victims, with high percentages in sex crimes and kidnappings. Those aged 12-17 are over 2 times more likely to be victims of violent crime than adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, with 1,200 children dying from abuse annually and 879,000 being victims. Child abuse has long-lasting negative effects on children and families. Local agencies often lack resources to protect children and families from domestic violence. Failure to pay child support contributes to neglect, leading to children living in poverty with inadequate education, healthcare, and housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Title I of the United States Code, Chapter 110, is amended to include Section 2260A, which addresses violence against children under 18 years of age. The section outlines penalties for those who willfully injure or attempt to injure a minor, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. Harsher penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. Section 2260A of Title I of the United States Code, Chapter 110, addresses violence against children under 18 years of age. It specifies that if the conduct occurs across state lines, involves the use of interstate commerce, or employs certain weapons that have traveled in interstate commerce, harsh penalties apply. Additionally, offenses under this section are subject to penalties outlined in section 1111 of the title. Amendment to Chapter 110 of Title 18, United States Code, addresses violence against children under 18 years of age. Penalties apply if the offense involves interstate commerce or certain weapons. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for federal crimes against children under 18. The Comptroller General will review state laws on crimes against children and report findings to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 102. Enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors upon request from State, tribal, or local governments. Priority is given to multi-state crimes and rural jurisdictions with limited resources. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors, prioritizing multi-state crimes and rural jurisdictions with limited resources. Federal assistance is provided to state and local law enforcement under Title II for grant programs. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, technical assistance, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. This includes training for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and developing specialized units targeting crimes against children. Developing and implementing effective police and prosecution policies to prevent, identify, and respond to crimes against children, expanding data collection systems to track arrests and convictions, enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and addressing the needs of Indian tribes. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants to provide education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for educational seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, and awareness efforts. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants cover emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims' mental health. States, tribal governments, local governments, or NGOs must submit applications to the Attorney General for grants. Applicants for grants must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds. They must also demonstrate consultation and coordination with victim services organizations when developing a plan to implement the grant. Applicants for grants must have experience in providing services to victims of crimes against children and certify that federal funds will supplement non-federal funds. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under section 202 must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously, collect family medical history, search missing person databases, and publicize the State's Safe Haven law within 3 years of this Act's enactment. The State must publicize its Safe Haven law and may deny a parent the ability to leave a newborn anonymously if signs of abuse are present. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. States must submit a report on their child welfare services program within 180 days of this Act, detailing record-keeping and child well-being verification processes. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices in this program. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment to nonpayment of child support, allowing deductions for recipients and adding unpaid amounts to the income of non-payers for tax purposes.
